maml:description.maml:para: Getting log file. By default function searching for log file inside C:\Logs
Name of PowerShell module that contains logs parameter in their Config.xml

The ProgressAction parameter in PowerShell is used to control how progress is displayed when running cmdlets or functions that support progress reporting. It is often available in cmdlets that involve long-running operations, such as downloading files, processing large datasets, or other intensive tasks.
Name of PowerShell module that contains logs parameter in their Config.xml

The ProgressAction parameter in PowerShell is used to control how progress is displayed when running cmdlets or functions that support progress reporting. It is often available in cmdlets that involve long-running operations, such as downloading files, processing large datasets, or other intensive tasks.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-LogFile -Module DBAdSync
Directory: C:\SyncManager\Logs
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a---- 1/8/2025 6:30 AM 4484 SyncManager-2025-01-08.log

maml:description.maml:para: Getting name of current log file.
The name of the current log file. This name will looks like logfile-2025-01-08.log Function will return log file with currnet date.

The ProgressAction parameter in PowerShell is used to control how progress is displayed when running cmdlets or functions that support progress reporting. It is often available in cmdlets that involve long-running operations, such as downloading files, processing large datasets, or other intensive tasks.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1 Get Currnet log file but furst we need to create it.
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-LogFile
Directory: C:\Logs
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a---- 1/8/2025 12:38 PM 0 logfile-2025-01-08.log
PS C:\> Get-LogFileName
Directory: C:\Logs
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a---- 1/8/2025 12:40 PM 0 logfile-2025-01-08.log

maml:description.maml:para: CmdLet shows current log file name it depends from config.xml

maml:description.maml:para: The Write-Log cmdlet helps us to build log file content.
The Write-Log cmdlet helps us to build log file content. We can choose what type of record to put in the log file.
Also we can choose start and end messages.
Specifies the message to output log.
Specifies name of PowerShell module that have config.xml with LoggingEnabled specified.
Please use .log in the end of the file name. Path to log file.

The ProgressAction parameter in PowerShell is used to control how progress is displayed when running cmdlets or functions that support progress reporting. It is often available in cmdlets that involve long-running operations, such as downloading files, processing large datasets, or other intensive tasks.
Specifies the message to output log.
Specifies name of PowerShell module that have config.xml with LoggingEnabled specified.
Please use .log in the end of the file name. Path to log file.

The ProgressAction parameter in PowerShell is used to control how progress is displayed when running cmdlets or functions that support progress reporting. It is often available in cmdlets that involve long-running operations, such as downloading files, processing large datasets, or other intensive tasks.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Write-Log -WriteDate -WriteBegin -Message "Success message" -MessageType SUCCESS PS C:\> Write-Log -WriteDate -Message "OPERATION message" -MessageType OPERATION PS C:\> Write-Log -WriteDate -Message "WARNING message" -MessageType WARNING PS C:\> Write-Log -WriteDate -Message "ERROR message" -MessageType ERROR PS C:\> Write-Log -WriteDate -WriteEnd PS C:\> Get-Content (Get-LogFilePath) --- START --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- 2025-01-11 13:56:50 SUCCESS: Success message 2025-01-11 13:56:50 OPERATION: OPERATION message 2025-01-11 13:56:50 WARNING: WARNING message 2025-01-11 13:56:50 ERROR: ERROR message 2025-01-11 13:56:50 --- END --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---
